original_title: Sri Lanka BESS solar plant with Australia backing may cost Rs48-49 a unit
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – An Australia backed solar plant with a battery energy storage system which can be dispatched at nigh peak may cost around 48 to 49 rupees a unit, Energy Minister Kanchana Wijeskera said.
“The Ceylon Electricity Board has to decide at what time to dispatch the plant,” Minister Wijesekera told reporters.
“Its value come in the night time when we use furnace oil and hydro power plants. Furnace oil costs about 65 to 70 rupees. If we compare LNG, it has been calculated 51 to 52 rupees.
“They have calculated at 48 to 49 rupees (about 15 US cents) for discharging with battery storage. I think that will financially advantageous and is good for the green economy and the environment.”
The plant, with a 700 MegWatts solar plant on a lake with 1500 MWh of storage was approved by the cabinet of minister two weeks ago.
The project has come under fire from opposition groups for not coming through competitive bidding.
Minister Wijesekera said it came from Expressions of Interest called in September 2021 to which attracted 560 proposals and 136 were shortlisted.
Negotiations took place for more than 2.5 years with a request for battery storage. (Colombo/Dec20/2023)
